openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Israel is characterized as a highly developed free-market economy, demonstrating advanced economic infrastructure and capabilities.
• Israel's prosperity enables it to maintain a sophisticated welfare state, supporting social services and economic stability.
• The country possesses a powerful modern military, which is believed to have a nuclear-weapons capability with a full nuclear triad (land, sea, and air-based nuclear forces).
• Israel's infrastructure is modern and comparable to that of developed nations, facilitating efficient economic activities.
• The high-technology sector in Israel is highly competitive, comparable to Silicon Valley in the United States.
• Israel has the second-largest number of startup companies globally, after the United States, though this ranking requires an update.
• It ranks third in the world for the number of NASDAQ-listed companies, following the United States and China.
• Major American technology companies such as Intel, Microsoft, and Apple established their first overseas R&D facilities in Israel.
• Over 400 multinational corporations, including IBM, Google, Hewlett-Packard, Cisco Systems, Facebook, and Motorola, have established R&D centers across Israel.
• As of 2025, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) estimated Israel's nominal GDP ranks 25th globally, making it one of the largest economies in the Middle East.
• The primary economic sectors in Israel are high-technology and industrial manufacturing.
• The Israeli diamond industry is a global hub for diamond cutting and polishing, accounting for 21% of all exports in 2017.
• Due to limited natural resources, Israel relies heavily on imports of petroleum, raw materials, wheat, motor vehicles, uncut diamonds, and production inputs.
• The country's energy dependence on imports is expected to decrease due to recent natural gas discoveries off its coast and the growth of its solar energy industry.
• Israel's high-quality higher education system and a highly motivated, educated population have been crucial in driving the country's high-tech boom and rapid economic development.
• The country has developed a robust educational infrastructure and a high-quality startup incubation system to promote innovative ideas and value-added goods and services.
• This infrastructure has fostered a high concentration of high-tech companies across various regions, supported by a strong venture capital industry.
• The "Silicon Wadi," Israel's central high-tech hub, is considered second in importance only to California's Silicon Valley.
• Many Israeli companies have been acquired by global multinationals for their innovative technologies and reliable, skilled personnel.
• In its early decades, Israel's economy was largely state-controlled and influenced by social democratic ideas.
• During the 1970s and 1980s, Israel implemented a series of free-market reforms and gradually liberalized its economy.
• Over the past three decades, Israel's economy has experienced significant growth, with GDP per capita increasing faster than wages.
• Israel is the most developed and advanced country in West Asia, holding the 17th largest foreign-exchange reserves in the world.
• It has the highest average wealth per adult in the Middle East, ranking 10th worldwide in financial assets per capita.
• Israel is the 9th largest arms exporter globally and has the highest number of billionaires in the Middle East, ranking 18th worldwide.
• In recent years, Israel has achieved among the highest GDP growth rates within the developed world, comparable to Ireland.
• The Economist ranked Israel as the 4th most successful economy among developed countries in 2022.
• The IMF estimated Israel's GDP at US$564 billion and GDP per capita at US$58,270 in 2023, ranking 13th worldwide in per capita income.
• Israel's economic indicators are comparable to other highly developed nations.
• Israel was invited to join the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) in 2010.
• The country has signed free trade agreements with the European Union, the United States, the European Free Trade Association, Turkey, Mexico, Canada, Ukraine, Jordan, and Egypt.
• In 2007, Israel became the first non-Latin American country to sign a free trade agreement with the Mercosur trade bloc.
• The section discusses the change in per capita GDP of Israel since 1950, noting that figures are inflation-adjusted to 2011 International dollars, indicating a long-term economic analysis.
• The British Mandate for Palestine, effective from 1920, aimed to restrict land purchases by Jewish immigrants, influencing the demographic and economic structure of the Jewish population.
• Due to these restrictions, the Jewish population was initially more urbanized and had a higher proportion engaged in industrial occupations, fostering a unique economic development.
• This development led to one of the region’s few economic growth miracles, characterized by a firm structure primarily driven by private businessmen rather than government intervention.

• In 1911, Russian Jewish businessman and engineer Moshe Novomeysky conducted the first survey of the Dead Sea, which resulted in the establishment of Palestine Potash Ltd. in 1930, later renamed the Dead Sea Works, marking early industrial activity.

• In 1923, businessman and hydraulic engineer Pinhas Rutenberg was granted an exclusive concession for the production and distribution of electric power, founding the Palestine Electric Company, which later became the Israel Electric Corporation.

• Between 1920 and 1924, Israel saw the establishment of some of its largest factories, including the Shemen Oil Company, Societe des Grand Moulins, Palestine Silicate Company, and Palestine Salt Company, indicating industrial growth.
• By 1937, Israel had 86 spinning and weaving factories employing approximately 1,500 workers, with capital and technical expertise supplied predominantly by Jewish professionals from Europe.
• The Ata textile plant in Kiryat Ata, established in 1934, became an iconic symbol of the Israeli textile industry.
• In 1939, the cornerstone was laid for the Naaman brick factory, one of the first kibbutz industries, which supplied construction materials during a period of rapid growth.
• During World War II, the textile industry experienced rapid development due to the interruption of European supplies, leading to increased local manufacturing for military needs.
• By 1943, the number of textile factories had increased to 250, employing 5,630 workers, with output increasing tenfold, demonstrating significant industrial expansion during wartime.
• Starting from 1924, trade fairs were held in Tel Aviv, serving as platforms for economic exchange and showcasing industrial progress.
• The Levant Fair was inaugurated in 1932, further promoting trade and economic development within the region.

• After Israel declared independence in 1948, the country faced a severe economic crisis characterized by the need to recover from the devastation of the 1948 Arab–Israeli War and to absorb hundreds of thousands of Jewish refugees from Europe and nearly one million from Arab countries.
• The economic crisis led Israel to adopt a policy of austerity from 1949 to 1959, during which unemployment was high and foreign currency reserves were scarce.

• In 1952, Israel signed an agreement with West Germany, stipulating that West Germany would pay Israel compensation for Jewish property stolen by the Nazis, Holocaust-related material claims, and refugee absorption costs.

• Over the subsequent 14 years, West Germany paid Israel a total of 3 billion marks, approximately US$714 million based on 1953–1955 conversion rates, or roughly US$7 billion in modern currency equivalents.
• The reparations from West Germany became a crucial part of Israel’s income, reaching as high as 87.5% of total income in 1956.
• Israel never established formal diplomatic relations with East Germany.
• In 1950, Israel launched Israel Bonds targeted at American and Canadian Jews to raise funds; by 1951, the bonds had raised over US$52 million.
• Many American Jews also made private donations to Israel, which in 1956 were estimated to total US$100 million annually.
• In 1957, bond sales contributed to 35% of Israel’s special development budget.
• Later in the 20th century, Israel became heavily reliant on economic aid from the United States, which also became its most important source of international political support.
• The funds from reparations, bonds, and private donations were invested in industrial and agricultural projects, enabling Israel to achieve economic self-sufficiency.
• Major projects financed included the Hadera power plant, Dead Sea Works, the National Water Carrier, port developments in Haifa, Ashdod, and Eilat, desalination plants, and national infrastructure.
• Post-independence, Israel prioritized establishing industries in development zones such as Lachish, Ashkelon, the Negev, and Galilee.

• The expansion of the textile industry was driven by profitable cotton cultivation; by the late 1960s, textiles became Israel’s second-largest industrial sector after foodstuffs, accounting for about 12% of industrial exports.

• The textile sector's profitability declined in the 1990s due to competition from low-cost East Asian labor, leading to subcontracting work to Israeli Arab sewing shops and later to Jordan and Egypt under the QIZ arrangement.

• In the early 2000s, Israeli companies operated 30 plants in Jordan, with exports reaching US$370 million annually, supplying retailers such as Marks & Spencer, The Gap, Victoria’s Secret, Walmart, Sears, Ralph Lauren, Calvin Klein, and Donna Karan.

• During its first two decades, Israel experienced rapid economic growth exceeding 10% annually, with wage-earner family expenditures rising 97% in real terms from 1950 to 1963 and per capita consumption increasing by 221% from 1955 to 1966.
• Investment shifts in the 1970s moved from agriculture and infrastructure to industry and defense, laying the groundwork for Israel’s technology sector.
• The 1973 Yom Kippur War marked a period of economic stagnation, with stalled growth, soaring inflation, and increased government spending.
• The 1983 Bank stock crisis was a significant financial event, and by 1984, inflation reached nearly 450% annually, projected to surpass 1000% in 1985.

• The economic stabilization plan implemented in 1985, along with market-oriented structural reforms, revitalized the economy, leading to rapid growth in the 1990s and serving as a model for other nations.

• Since the early 1990s, two key developments transformed Israel’s economy: waves of Jewish immigration from the former USSR, bringing over one million highly educated immigrants, now constituting about 15% of the population, and the peace process initiated at the Madrid conference of October 1991, culminating in the 1994 peace treaty with Jordan.
• The influx of Soviet Jewish immigrants contributed significant scientific and technical expertise, bolstering Israel’s burgeoning technology sector.

• In the early 2000s, Israel’s economy declined due to the collapse of the dot-com bubble, the Second Intifada, which increased security costs and reduced investment and tourism, causing unemployment to reach double digits; in one quarter of 2000, growth was 10%, and in 2002, the economy shrank by about 4% in one quarter.

• Israel recovered by expanding exports to new markets, especially in East Asia, driven by a rebound in the tech sector and increased global demand for computer software and security products post-9/11.
• The demand for Israeli security and defense technologies surged after 9/11, facilitating increased exports due to prior investments in the tech sector aimed at reducing domestic unemployment.
• In 2006, foreign investment in Israel totaled US$13 billion, according to the Manufacturers Association of Israel, reflecting increased international confidence despite regional instability.

• Israel’s total gross external debt is approximately US$95 billion, representing about 41.6% of GDP, but since 2001, Israel has been a net lender nation, with a net external debt surplus of US$60 billion as of June 2012.
• Israel maintained a current account surplus of about 3% of GDP in 2010, and in 2023, the account surplus reached US$25.3 billion.

• The Israeli economy demonstrated resilience during the late-2000s recession, maintaining positive GDP growth in 2009 and ending the decade with a lower unemployment rate than many Western countries.
• Israel’s economic resilience is attributed to its status as a net lender, conservative macroeconomic policies by the government and the Bank of Israel, and strategic financial regulations.
• Notably, the government resisted pressure from banks to allocate large sums of public money to bail them out early in the crisis, limiting risky banking behavior.

• The implementation of recommendations from the Bach’ar commission in the early to mid-2000s, which advocated for separating banks’ depository and investment activities, helped reduce systemic risk; this contrasted with the U.S. trend of easing such restrictions, which increased risk-taking in American financial systems.
• American investors constitute the most significant foreign investor group in Israel today.
• In May 2007, Israel was invited to initiate accession discussions with the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD).
• In May 2010, the OECD conducted a vote and unanimously decided to invite Israel to become a member, despite objections from Palestinian representatives.
• Israel officially became a full member of the OECD on 7 September 2010.
• The OECD praised Israel for its scientific and technological progress, highlighting its significant achievements.
• The OECD described Israel as having "produced outstanding outcomes on a world scale" in terms of scientific and technological advancements.
• Despite experiencing economic prosperity, the Israeli economy faces numerous challenges that are categorized into short-term and long-term issues.
• In the short term, Israel's inability to replicate its success in the telecommunications industry across other emerging sectors limits its overall economic growth prospects.
• The country has struggled to develop large multinational corporations over the past decade, raising concerns about its capacity to generate employment in advanced industries.
• Long-term challenges include a high dependency on the increasing population of Ultra-Orthodox Jews, who exhibit low levels of official labor force participation among men.
• This demographic trend could result in a significantly lower employment-to-population ratio and an increased dependency ratio in the future, impacting economic sustainability.
• Stanley Fischer, the governor of the Bank of Israel, has stated that rising poverty levels among the Ultra-Orthodox community are detrimental to the Israeli economy.
• Data published by Ian Fursman indicates that 60% of poor households in Israel belong to the Haredi Jewish community and Israeli Arabs.
• The Haredi Jews and Israeli Arabs together constitute approximately 25–28% of the total Israeli population.

• Several organizations, including The Kemach Foundation, Gvahim, Jerusalem Village, and The Jerusalem Business Networking Forum, are actively addressing these economic challenges through initiatives such as job placement services and networking events.
• Following the Gaza war, Israeli stock markets and the national currency experienced a sharp decline, indicating significant economic instability.
• It is estimated that Israel will incur approximately $400 billion in economic losses over the next decade as a consequence of the conflict.

• The projected economic shock is expected to be substantial, with 90% of the total loss attributed to indirect effects such as reduced investment, disruptions in the labor market, and hindered productivity growth.
• In August 2024, Fitch Ratings downgraded Israel's credit rating, reflecting increased financial risk and economic uncertainty resulting from the conflict.
• The Bank of Israel has estimated that war-related costs from 2023 to 2025 could reach up to $55.6 billion, encompassing military expenses, reconstruction, and other war-associated expenditures.
• The conflict led to a 27% decrease in consumer spending, indicating a significant decline in domestic economic activity.
• Imports into Israel fell by 42%, demonstrating a substantial reduction in international trade and supply chain disruptions.
• Exports declined by 18%, further impacting Israel’s trade balance and overall economic performance during the post-war period.
• The 2024 Henley & Partners Report states that approximately 1,700 millionaires have left Israel since 2023 in search of investment migration opportunities.
• The migration of these high-net-worth individuals is motivated by the desire to mitigate risks and explore alternative residency options.
• The report highlights a significant 232% increase in investment migration applications from Israeli citizens in 2023 compared to previous years.
• Contributing factors to this surge include a 5% depreciation of the Israeli shekel against the US dollar.
• There was also a 10% decline in real estate prices in Tel Aviv, Israel’s major economic hub.
• Additional drivers of this trend are Israel’s increasing international isolation and the financial pressures stemming from the war in 2023.
• The Red Sea crisis, instigated by Houthi attacks, has significantly impacted the Israeli economy by disrupting maritime shipping routes.
• The crisis has led to increased operational costs for shipping and resulted in job losses within the maritime sector.
• The port of Eilat, Israel's southern gateway, has experienced near-complete shutdowns and faces bankruptcy risks, prompting calls for government assistance.
• Approximately 50% of the port's workforce is at risk of losing their jobs due to the crisis.
• Many shipping companies are avoiding the Red Sea entirely, rerouting their vessels around Africa, which extends the journey by three weeks.
• The rerouting around Africa increases shipping costs substantially, adding to the economic strain.
• Insurance premiums for ships operating in the Red Sea have surged dramatically, with some Israeli ships experiencing a 250% increase in insurance costs.
• Certain ships have been denied insurance coverage altogether due to the heightened risks associated with the conflict zone.

• On 19 July 2024, the International Court of Justice issued an advisory opinion stating that countries must not recognize, assist, or support the illegal circumstances resulting from Israel's occupation of Palestinian territories.

• The ICJ declared that all nations are required to avoid engaging in any economic or trade relations with Israel concerning the Occupied Palestinian Territories (OPT) or any areas that could reinforce Israel's unlawful presence there.
• The advisory emphasized the necessity for countries to take measures to prevent trade or investment activities that contribute to maintaining the illegal situation established by Israel in the OPT.

• On 26 May 2023, the European Trade Union Confederation (ETUC), which represents over 45 million workers and their trade unions across Europe, announced a boycott of products produced in illegal Israeli settlements located in the occupied Palestinian territories.
• The ETUC highlighted the importance of implementing regulatory measures to prohibit the import and export of goods manufactured in these illicit settlements by entities within the European Union.
• The measures advocated by the ETUC are aligned with EU treaties and international law, emphasizing the need to prevent economic support for illegal settlements.
• Following the 2023 Israeli judicial reform, banks in Israel experienced a significant surge in fund withdrawals, occurring at a rate ten times higher than normal.
• Bank executives warned that these political changes could negatively impact the Israeli economy, including a decline in the value of the shekel and a loss of investor confidence.

• A report from The Times of Israel, dated March 5, 2023, indicated that as the shekel depreciated against the US dollar and euro, the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange (TASE) also declined relative to stock markets in the European Union and the United States.
• Numerous companies, especially within the technology sector, have withdrawn their investments from Israel, contributing to an outflow of over $4 billion in just a few weeks.

• The table presents key economic indicators of Israel from 1980 to 2021, with IMF staff estimates for 2022–2027, highlighting data such as GDP, GDP per capita, inflation, unemployment, government debt, and growth rates.
• Inflation rates under 5% are indicated in green within the table.

• In 1980, Israel’s GDP measured approximately 28.4 billion US dollars in purchasing power parity (PPP), with a GDP per capita of about 7,240.1 US dollars PPP; nominal GDP was 24.9 billion US dollars, and nominal GDP per capita was 6,356.5 US dollars.
• The GDP growth rate in 1980 was 3.6%, with inflation at 316.6%, and unemployment at 4.8%; government debt as a percentage of GDP was not available.

• By 1981, GDP increased to 32.5 billion US dollars PPP, with a GDP per capita of 8,240.4 US dollars PPP; nominal GDP rose to 26.4 billion US dollars, and nominal GDP per capita was 6,687.2 US dollars.
• Inflation decreased significantly from 316.6% in 1980 to 116.8% in 1981, and unemployment slightly increased to 5.1%.
• In 1982, GDP reached 35.0 billion US dollars PPP, with a GDP per capita of 8,717.7 US dollars PPP; nominal GDP was 28.3 billion US dollars, and nominal GDP per capita was 7,040.6 US dollars.
• Inflation further declined to 120.4%, with unemployment at 5.0%, indicating ongoing economic adjustments.
• The trend of rising GDP continued through the 1980s, with 1987 marking a GDP of 49.6 billion US dollars PPP and a GDP per capita of 11,355.8 US dollars PPP; nominal GDP was 40.8 billion US dollars.
• In 1988, GDP increased to 53.2 billion US dollars PPP, with a GDP per capita of 11,975.7 US dollars PPP; nominal GDP was 50.6 billion US dollars, and inflation was at 16.2%.
• The early 1990s saw continued growth, with 1992 GDP at 73.5 billion US dollars PPP and GDP per capita at 14,340.4 US dollars PPP; nominal GDP was 77.0 billion US dollars.
• The 1990s experienced rapid economic expansion, with GDP reaching 108.8 billion US dollars PPP in 1997, and GDP per capita at 18,677.3 US dollars PPP; nominal GDP was 118.9 billion US dollars.
• Inflation rates generally decreased over the decade, reaching 5.4% in 1998 and 5.2% in 1999, with unemployment declining to around 9.0–11.1%.
• The early 2000s showed steady growth, with GDP at 133.4 billion US dollars PPP in 2000 and 136.8 billion in 2001; GDP per capita was approximately 21,216.5 and 21,258.3 US dollars PPP respectively.
• During 2000–2002, inflation was notably low, at around 1.1–5.7%, and unemployment ranged from 10.9% to 12.9%.
• From 2003 onward, Israel’s economy continued to expand, with GDP reaching 154.4 billion US dollars PPP in 2004 and 180.5 billion in 2006, with corresponding increases in GDP per capita.
• The global financial crisis of 2008 saw GDP at 206.8 billion US dollars PPP, with a GDP per capita of 28,309.7 US dollars PPP; inflation was 4.6%, and unemployment was 7.7%.
• Post-2008, the economy maintained growth, with GDP at 242.0 billion US dollars PPP in 2011 and 255.7 billion in 2012, with GDP per capita exceeding 31,000 US dollars PPP.
• In 2013, GDP reached 280.0 billion US dollars PPP, with a GDP per capita of 34,755.0 US dollars PPP; inflation was 1.5%, and unemployment was 6.2%.

• The COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 caused a contraction with GDP at 386.4 billion US dollars PPP, a slight decrease in GDP per capita, and a negative growth rate of -1.9%; inflation was at -0.6%, and unemployment rose to 4.3%.

• In 2021, Israel’s GDP increased significantly to 437.1 billion US dollars PPP, with a GDP per capita of 46,659.3 US dollars PPP, and a robust growth rate of 8.6%; inflation was 1.5%, and unemployment was 5.0%.
• Projections for 2022 estimate GDP at 496.8 billion US dollars PPP, with GDP per capita at 52,173.1 US dollars PPP, and growth of 6.1%, with inflation at 4.5% and unemployment at 3.9%.
• For 2023, GDP is forecasted at 530.0 billion US dollars PPP, with GDP per capita of 54,750.6 US dollars PPP, and a growth rate of 3.0%, inflation at 3.6%, and unemployment at 3.8%.
• The trend of steady growth continues into 2024 with GDP at 557.4 billion US dollars PPP, GDP per capita at 56,633.2 US dollars PPP, and growth of 3.0%, inflation at 2.5%, and unemployment at 3.7%.
• In 2025, projections show GDP reaching 585.1 billion US dollars PPP, with GDP per capita of 58,474.2 US dollars PPP, growth of 3.1%, inflation at 2.2%, and unemployment at 3.7%.
• By 2026, GDP is expected to be 615.6 billion US dollars PPP, with GDP per capita of 60,526.4 US dollars PPP, and growth of 3.3%, inflation at 2.0%, and unemployment at 3.7%.
• The 2027 forecast indicates GDP at 649.5 billion US dollars PPP, with GDP per capita of 62,813.2 US dollars PPP, and a growth rate of 3.5%, inflation at 1.9%, and unemployment at 3.7%.
• The Kibbutzim, collective communities in Israel traditionally based on agriculture, played a significant role in the country's economy until the late 1970s.
• In 2017, agriculture contributed approximately 2.4% to Israel's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• The total labor force in Israel was about 2.7 million people, with 2.6% employed in agricultural production and 6.3% employed in services related to agriculture.
• Israel imports approximately 80% of its grain consumption, indicating a heavy reliance on imported cereal grains.
• Despite grain imports, Israel is largely self-sufficient in other agricultural products and foodstuffs.
• Historically, farmers in the region have cultivated citrus fruits such as grapefruits, oranges, and lemons for centuries.
• Citrus fruits remain Israel's major agricultural export product.
• Israel is one of the world's leading countries in greenhouse-food exports, showcasing advanced horticultural technology.
• The country also produces and exports flowers and cotton as part of its agricultural output.
• Annually, Israel exports over $1.3 billion worth of agricultural products, including farm produce and agricultural inputs and technology.
• The agricultural inputs and technology sector accounts for approximately $1.2 billion of the exports each year.
• Israeli technological innovations in agriculture and water technology have provided the Israeli AgTech sector with a competitive advantage.
• These innovations enable Israeli AgTech companies to operate successfully in numerous countries worldwide, expanding Israel’s influence in global agricultural markets.
• Jerusalem Venture Partners (JVP), based in Jerusalem, is one of Israel's largest venture capital firms.
• Israel hosts over 100 active venture capital funds operating nationwide, managing approximately US$10 billion.

• In 2004, international foreign funds from various nations committed over 50% of the total dollars invested in Israel, highlighting the country's strong reputation as an attractive destination for foreign investment.

• The Israeli venture capital sector has experienced rapid development since the early 1990s, currently comprising about 70 active venture capital funds, including 14 international VCs with Israeli offices.
• Israel's venture capital and business-incubator industries have significantly contributed to financing the country's high-tech sector, which is flourishing.
• In 2008, venture capital investment in Israel increased by 19%, reaching a total of $1.9 billion.
• The Yozma Fund, established in the 1990s, was instrumental in initiating Israel’s venture capital industry, raising approximately $8 billion in total.
• Between 1991 and 2000, Israel’s annual private venture capital outlays surged nearly 60-fold, from $58 million to $3.3 billion.
• During the same period, the number of companies launched by Israeli venture funds increased from 100 to 800.
• Israel’s information-technology revenues grew from $1.6 billion to $12.5 billion between 1991 and 2000.
• By 1999, Israel ranked second globally after the United States in private equity capital invested as a share of GDP.
• Israel led the world in the proportion of its economic growth attributable to high-tech ventures, accounting for 70%.
• The high-tech sector’s growth has been heavily financed by Israel’s vibrant venture capital industry, comprising numerous successful private equity and venture capital firms.
• The 2008 financial crisis negatively impacted the availability of venture capital within Israel.

• In 2009, Israeli mergers and acquisitions (M&A) totaled 63 deals worth $2.54 billion, representing a 7% decrease from 2008’s $2.74 billion across 82 deals, and a 33% decline from 2007’s $3.79 billion across 87 deals.
• Many Israeli high-tech companies have been acquired by global multinational corporations for their profitable technologies and strong management and administrative personnel.

• Major international investment banks, pension funds, and insurance companies with a presence in Israel include Goldman Sachs, Bear Stearns, Deutsche Bank, JP Morgan, Credit Suisse First Boston, Merrill Lynch, CalPERS, Ontario Teachers Pension Plan, and AIG.
• Israel has a small but rapidly growing hedge fund industry; between 2007 and 2012, the number of active hedge funds doubled to 60.
• From 2006 to 2012, Israel-based hedge funds experienced a 162% increase, managing a total of $2 billion (₪8 billion) and employing approximately 300 people.
• The hedge fund industry in Israel is attracting increasing international investor interest, especially from the United States.
• In 2022, Tel Aviv was ranked 53rd on the Global Financial Centres Index.
• In 2023, despite war, a legal reform, and rising interest rates causing market uncertainty, about 40% of companies traded on the Tel Aviv Stock Exchange continued paying dividends.
• The energy, oil, gas, banking, and financial services sectors notably maintained dividend distributions in 2023.

• The total dividends distributed to public shareholders in 2023 reached a record high of approximately 16.8 billion shekels, representing about 62% of the total dividends paid, up from 55% (15.8 billion shekels) in 2022.
• The remaining dividend amount was allocated to stakeholders.
• The average dividend yield of exchange-listed companies in 2023 was approximately 2.9%, slightly higher than 2.8% in 2022.
• The 2023 dividend yield marked the highest return since 2017 and surpassed the 2022 record, despite the market value decreasing by about 9% compared to 2022.
• The total dividend paid in 2023 was only about 5% lower than in 2022, even though the overall market value declined.
• Science and technology constitute one of Israel's most highly developed and industrialized sectors, playing a significant role in the national economy.
• The modern Israeli high technology ecosystem is highly optimized and accounts for a substantial portion of the country's economic activity.

• Israel has a notably high percentage of its population engaged in scientific and technological inquiry, with research and development (R&D) expenditure relative to gross domestic product (GDP) among the highest worldwide.
• There are 140 scientists and technicians per 10,000 employees in Israel, compared to 85 per 10,000 in the United States and 83 per 10,000 in Japan.
• Israel ranks fourth globally in scientific activity, as measured by the number of scientific publications per million citizens.
• The country’s share of worldwide scientific articles is nearly ten times higher than its proportion of the global population.
• Israel hosts over 1,400 life science companies, including approximately 300 pharmaceutical companies, 600 medical device companies, 450 digital health companies, and 468 biotechnology firms.

• Israeli scientists, engineers, and technicians have significantly contributed to advancements across multiple fields, including natural sciences, agricultural sciences, computer sciences, electronics, genetics, medicine, optics, and solar energy, as well as various engineering disciplines.
• Israel possesses one of the world's most technologically literate populations.
• The country has the second-largest number of startup companies globally, second only to the United States, and remains a major global hub for technology startups.
• As of 2013, Israel was creating approximately 200 new startups annually.
• By 2019, nearly 7,000 active startups were operating across Israel.
• In 2021, Israel had 79 tech unicorns (privately held startups valued at over $1 billion), with 32 headquartered within the country.
• Over one-third of the world's cybersecurity unicorns in 2021 were Israeli.
• Israel is home to nearly 400 research and development centers owned by multinational corporations, including Google, Microsoft, and Intel.

• The country is a major semiconductor design hub, hosting numerous chip design centers owned by leading multinational firms, and is recognized for having one of the most advanced chip design industries globally.
• In 2021, 37 multinational corporations operated in Israel within the semiconductor sector.
• Tel Aviv was named by _Newsweek_ in 1998 as one of the ten most influential technological cities worldwide.
• In 2012, Tel Aviv was ranked as the second-best city for high-tech startups, behind California.
• In 2013, _The Boston Globe_ ranked Tel Aviv as the second-best city for business startups, after Silicon Valley.
• In 2020, StartupBlink ranked Israel as having the third-best startup ecosystem globally, following the United States and the United Kingdom.
• Israel is frequently referred to as the "Start-Up Nation" and the "Silicon Valley of the Middle East" due to its prolific and dynamic startup culture.
• Programs such as TAVtech Ventures and TAMID Group facilitate exploration of Israel’s "Start-Up Nation" economy for entrepreneurs and investors.
• The country's high-tech success is partly attributed to the widespread service in the Israel Defense Forces, which develops talent that fuels the high-tech industry after discharge.
• As of 2019, the industry faced a significant shortage of technology specialists, with 15% of high-tech positions unfilled.
• The largest unfilled job positions (31%) are in software engineering specialties, including DevOps, back-end development, data science, machine learning, and artificial intelligence.
• Salaries for high-tech specialists in Israel increased substantially due to the labor shortage.
• To address the talent gap, Israeli IT companies increasingly employ workers from abroad, with about 25% of their workforce being overseas hires.
• The primary offshoring destinations are Ukraine (45%) and the United States (16%).
• In 2017, the Israeli Council for Higher Education launched a five-year program aiming to increase the number of graduates in computer science and engineering by 40%.
• The Levant Basin contains known oil and gas fields, as reported by the US Energy Information Administration (EIA).
• Since 1980, Israel's consumption of fossil fuel energy sources has undergone significant changes, with notable trends in coal and natural gas use.
• Coal consumption in Israel has increased steadily since 1980, when it was virtually negligible.
• Natural gas consumption was nearly zero in 2003 but has experienced a steady rise since then.
• Historically, Israel depended heavily on external imports to meet its energy needs, with energy import expenditures exceeding 5% of the country's GDP annually in 2009.
• The transportation sector in Israel primarily relies on gasoline and diesel fuel for its energy requirements.
• The majority of Israel's electricity production is generated using imported coal.
• As of 2013, Israel was importing approximately 100 million barrels of oil annually.
• The country has negligible domestic crude oil reserves, making it heavily reliant on imports for oil.
• Israel possesses domestic natural gas resources, which were discovered in more significant quantities starting in 2009 after decades of unsuccessful exploration efforts.
• Until the early 2000s, natural gas consumption in Israel was minimal, indicating limited utilization of this energy resource during that period.

• In the late 1990s, the Israeli government made a strategic decision to promote the use of natural gas, citing environmental benefits, cost advantages, and the goal of diversifying energy resources as primary motivations.

• At that time, Israel lacked domestic natural gas sources; the expectation was that natural gas would be imported from overseas primarily in the form of liquefied natural gas (LNG) and via a future pipeline from Egypt.
• The pipeline from Egypt, which was planned as part of these import strategies, eventually became the Arish–Ashkelon pipeline, facilitating natural gas transfer from Egypt to Israel.

• Israel planned for the Israel Electric Corporation to build several natural gas-powered power plants to increase domestic electricity generation efficiency and reduce reliance on other fossil fuels.
• The government also planned to establish a national gas distribution grid to supply natural gas across the country and to develop an LNG import terminal to facilitate overseas gas imports.
• Natural gas usage in Israel increased steadily over the years, with consumption figures in billion cubic meters (BCM) per year as follows:
• 2018: 10.1 BCM (projected)
• 2020: 11.1 BCM (projected)
• 2022: 11.7 BCM (projected)
• 2024: 13 BCM (projected)
• 2026: 14.3 BCM (projected)
• 2028: 15.3 BCM (projected)
• 2030: 16.8 BCM (projected)
• These figures demonstrate a consistent upward trend in natural gas consumption, reflecting Israel’s increasing reliance on natural gas as an energy source over the period.

• In 2000, a natural gas field with a capacity of 33 billion cubic meters (BCM), equivalent to 1,200 billion cubic feet (BCF), was discovered offshore Ashkelon, with commercial production commencing in 2004.

• By 2014, this offshore Ashkelon gas field was nearly depleted, earlier than initially expected, due to increased extraction efforts to compensate for the loss of imported Egyptian gas following unrest associated with the fall of the Mubarak regime in 2011.

• In 2009, a significant gas discovery named Tamar was made, with proven reserves of 223 BCM (7.9×10^12 cubic feet), and a total of 307 BCM (10.8 trillion cubic feet) including probable reserves, located in deep water approximately 90 km (60 miles) west of Haifa.
• Also in 2009, a smaller gas field with reserves of 15 BCM (530×10^9 cubic feet) was identified nearer the Israeli coastline.

• Since 2010, results from 3D seismic surveys and test drilling have confirmed the existence of the Leviathan gas deposit, estimated at 621 BCM (21.9×10^12 cubic feet), situated in a large underwater geological formation near the Tamar field.

• The Tamar field began commercial production on 30 March 2013 after four years of development, aiming to bolster the Israeli economy which had suffered losses exceeding ₪20 billion (Israeli new shekels) between 2011 and 2013 due to disrupted gas supplies from Egypt.

• The disruption of Egyptian gas supplies was linked to political unrest and Egypt's decision to indefinitely suspend its gas supply agreement with Israel, leading Israel and Jordan to import more expensive and polluting liquid heavy fuels as alternative energy sources.
• The energy crisis in Israel was alleviated once the Tamar field came online in 2013, restoring domestic gas supplies.

• Jordan entered into a US$10 billion, 15-year gas supply agreement with Israel, which involves the delivery of 45 BCM from the Leviathan field scheduled to start in late 2019, with an estimated annual savings of US$600 million in energy costs for Jordan.
• In 2018, the owners of the Tamar and Leviathan fields announced negotiations with a consortium of Egyptian firms for the supply of up to 64 BCM of gas over 10 years, valued at up to US$15 billion.
• In early 2012, the Israeli cabinet announced plans to establish a sovereign wealth fund called "the Israeli Citizens' Fund."
• The Noa North gas field was discovered in 1999, produced from 2012 to 2014, with an original estimated size of 50 billion cubic feet (1.4 billion cubic meters), but is now depleted.
• The Mari-B gas field was discovered in 2000, produced from 2004 to 2015, with an original size of 1 trillion cubic feet (28 billion cubic meters), now depleted.
• The Tamar field, discovered in 2009, began production in 2013, with an estimated size of 10.8 trillion cubic feet (310 billion cubic meters).
• The Dalit field, also discovered in 2009, is not in production and has an estimated size of 700 billion cubic feet (20 billion cubic meters).
• The Leviathan field was discovered in 2010, scheduled to start production in 2019, with an estimated size of 22 trillion cubic feet (620 billion cubic meters).
• The Dolphin field was discovered in 2011, not in production, with an estimated size of 81.3 billion cubic feet (2.30 billion cubic meters).
• The Tanin field was discovered in 2012, not in production, with an estimated size ranging from 1.2 to 1.3 trillion cubic feet (34 to 37 billion cubic meters).
• The Karish field was discovered in 2013, began production in 2022, with an estimated size between 2.3 and 3.6 trillion cubic feet (65 to 102 billion cubic meters).
• Since the founding of the State of Israel through the mid-2010s, the Israel Electric Corporation (IEC), a state-owned utility, held an effective monopoly on power generation within the country.
• In 2010, the IEC sold a total of 52,037 gigawatt-hours (GWh) of electricity.
• Up until the mid-2010s, Israel faced a persistently low operating reserve, primarily because the country functions as an "electricity island," meaning its electrical grid is isolated.

• Unlike most countries that can import power from neighboring nations during shortages, Israel's grid is unconnected to those of neighboring countries, mainly due to political reasons and the underdeveloped state of power systems in Jordan and Egypt.
• The power systems of Jordan and Egypt struggle to meet their own domestic demand, with their per-capita electric generation being less than one-fifth of Israel's.

• Despite low operating reserves, Israel maintained sufficient generation and transmission capacity to meet domestic electricity needs, and historically, rolling blackouts have been quite rare even during periods of extreme demand.

• Beginning in the second half of the 2000s, the Israeli government initiated measures to increase electricity supply and operating reserves, and to reduce the IEC's monopoly to foster competition in the electricity market.
• These measures included instructing the IEC to build several new power stations and encouraging private investment in electricity generation.
• By 2015, the IEC's share of the total installed national electricity generation capacity had decreased to approximately 75%, with the company owning about 13.6 GW of installed capacity.
• Since 2010, independent power producers (IPPs) have constructed three new gas-fired combined cycle power stations with a combined capacity of approximately 2.2 GW.

• Industrial concerns have built on-premises cogeneration facilities with a total electricity output of about 1 GW, which are licensed to sell surplus electricity to the national grid at competitive rates.
• A 300 MW pumped storage facility was under construction, with two additional such facilities in planning, along with several solar power plants.

• Israel and Cyprus are considering implementing the EuroAsia Interconnector project, which involves laying a 2000 MW high-voltage direct current (HVDC) undersea power cable connecting Israel, Cyprus, and Greece, thereby linking Israel to the broader European power grid.
• If realized, the EuroAsia Interconnector would enhance Israel's operating reserves and enable the export of surplus electricity abroad.

• In 2016, Israel's total electricity production was 67.2 GWh, with 55.2% generated using natural gas and 43.8% using coal, marking the first time natural gas surpassed coal in electricity generation share.
• The share of total electricity generation capacity at full output by plant type in 2010 was as follows: coal 39.7%, fuel oil 3.4%, natural gas 39.8%, and diesel 18.9%.
• In 2010, the total annual electricity generation by fuel source was: coal 61.0%, fuel oil 0.9%, natural gas 36.6%, and diesel 1.5%.
• The Negev Desert hosts Israel's solar research industry, including the National Solar Energy Center and the Arava Valley, which is recognized as Israel's sunniest region.
• Solar power development in Israel has historical roots dating back to the country's founding period.
• In the 1950s, Levi Yissar pioneered the development of solar water heaters to address Israel's energy shortages during its early years.
• By 1967, approximately 1 in 20 Israeli households utilized solar water heating systems, with a total of 50,000 solar heaters sold nationwide.
• The 1973 oil crisis acted as a catalyst for further solar energy innovation in Israel.
• Harry Zvi Tabor, regarded as the father of Israel's solar industry, developed a prototype solar water heater during this period.
• The solar water heater prototype created by Harry Zvi Tabor is now used in over 90% of Israeli homes, indicating widespread adoption and integration into domestic energy systems.
• Israel possesses a substantial industrial capacity characterized by a well-developed chemical industry primarily oriented toward export markets.
• The majority of chemical manufacturing plants are situated in Ramat Hovav, the Haifa Bay area, and near the Dead Sea, facilitating strategic geographic distribution.

• Israel Chemicals (ICL) is one of the country's largest fertilizer and chemical companies, with its subsidiary, Dead Sea Works in Sdom, ranking as the world's fourth-largest producer and supplier of potash products.
• Dead Sea Works also produces magnesium chloride, industrial salts, de-icers, bath salts, table salt, and raw materials used in the cosmetic industry, diversifying its product portfolio.

• The manufacturing sector in Israel includes industrial production of metals, machinery, electrical equipment, construction materials, consumer goods, textiles, and food processing, indicating a broad industrial base.
• Machinery and equipment manufacturing in Israel encompasses computer equipment, medical devices, agricultural machinery, and robots, highlighting technological innovation and diversification.

• Israel maintains a successful semiconductor device fabrication industry, with several semiconductor manufacturing facilities operating within the country, contributing to high-tech industrial output.

• Israel Aerospace Industries (IAI) is among the country's largest employers, primarily producing aviation, space, and defense products; in 2017, IAI had an order backlog valued at 11.4 billion US dollars.
• Numerous other aerospace companies operate in Israel, mainly serving as sub-suppliers specializing in machining, electronic systems and components, and composite materials.
• Israel is a major manufacturer and exporter of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs), establishing a significant presence in the global UAV market.
• The country has a notable pharmaceutical industry, with Teva Pharmaceutical Industries being one of the world's largest pharmaceutical companies, employing 40,000 people as of 2011.

• Teva specializes in generic and proprietary pharmaceuticals as well as active pharmaceutical ingredients, and it is recognized as the largest generic drug manufacturer globally and ranks among the top 15 pharmaceutical companies worldwide.
• Israel's shipbuilding industry is represented by Israel Shipyards, which operates one of the largest shipbuilding and repair facilities in the Eastern Mediterranean.

• Israel Shipyards constructs merchant ships and other civilian watercraft, along with machinery for ports and heavy industries, serving the civilian market, and also builds naval vessels for defense purposes.
• Israel is one of the world's three major centers for polished diamonds, alongside Belgium and India.
• In 2012, Israel's net polished diamond exports declined by 22.8%, decreasing from $7.2 billion in 2011 to $5.56 billion.
• Net exports of rough diamonds from Israel fell by 20.1% in 2012, totaling $2.8 billion.
• Net exports of polished diamonds decreased by 24.9% in 2012, amounting to $4.3 billion.
• Net imports of rough diamonds into Israel dropped by 12.9% in 2012, totaling $3.8 billion.
• During the Great Recession, particularly affected were the Eurozone and the United States, leading to declines in Israel's diamond trade.
• The United States is Israel's largest export market for polished diamonds, accounting for 36% of the overall export market.
• Hong Kong is the second-largest market, representing 28% of Israel's polished diamond exports.
• Belgium ranks third, with an 8% share of Israel's polished diamond export market.
• As of 2016, cut diamonds were Israel’s largest export product, comprising 23.2% of all exports.
• Israel is one of the world's major exporters of military equipment, accounting for 10% of the global total in 2007.

• In 2010, three Israeli companies—Elbit Systems, Israel Aerospace Industries, and RAFAEL—were listed on the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute (SIPRI) index of the world's top 100 arms-producing and military service companies.
• The defense industry in Israel is a strategically important sector, serving as a large employer within the country and playing a significant role in the global arms market.
• As of 2012, Israel was the 11th largest arms exporter in the world.
• Total arms transfer agreements involving Israel exceeded US$12.9 billion between 2004 and 2011.
• Israeli defense equipment exports reached US$7 billion in 2012, representing a 20% increase compared to the defense-related exports in 2011.
• The majority of Israeli defense exports are sold to the United States and Europe, with other major markets including Southeast Asia and Latin America.
• India remains Israel's largest arms market, making it a major recipient of Israeli defense exports.
• Israel is considered the leading exporter of unmanned aerial vehicles (UAVs) globally.
• According to SIPRI, Israeli defense companies were responsible for 41% of all drones exported worldwide during 2001–2011.
• In 2021, Israel's defense exports reached US$11.2 billion in sales.
• Exports to Arab countries that joined the Abraham Accords constituted approximately 7% of all Israeli defense exports.
• Israel is a major tourist destination, particularly for individuals of Jewish ancestry.
• In 2019, Israel received 4.55 million foreign tourists.
• The number of tourists in 2019 represented approximately one tourist for every two Israelis.
• There was a 25% increase in tourist arrivals from 2016 to 2019.
• Tourism contributed ₪20 billion to Israel's economy in 2019, marking an all-time record at that time.
• The most popular paid visited site in Israel is Masada.
• In 2016, Israel's goods exports totaled US$55.8 billion, while its imports amounted to US$61.9 billion, indicating a trade deficit in goods.
• In 2017, Israel's total exports (including goods and services) reached US$102.3 billion, with imports at US$96.7 billion, resulting in a trade surplus in services.
• Israel typically maintains a modest trade deficit in goods due to imports of raw materials, crude oil, production inputs, and finished consumer goods.
• The country's exports are predominantly high-value-added items such as electronic components, high-technology equipment, tools, machinery, cut diamonds, refined petrochemicals, and pharmaceuticals.

• Israel generally posts a substantial trade surplus in services, driven by tourism and industries like software development, engineering services, biomedical, and scientific research and development.
• Overall external trade is positive, contributing to a significant current account surplus that stood at 4.7% of GDP as of 2017.
• The United States is Israel's largest trading partner, and Israel ranks as the 26th-largest trading partner of the U.S.
• Two-way trade between Israel and the U.S. totaled approximately US$24.5 billion in 2010, up from US$12.7 billion in 1997.
• U.S. exports to Israel include computers, integrated circuits, aircraft parts, defense equipment, wheat, and automobiles.
• Israel's main exports to the U.S. comprise cut diamonds, jewelry, integrated circuits, printing machinery, and telecommunications equipment.
• Israel and the U.S. signed a free trade agreement (FTA) in 1985, which gradually eliminated tariffs on most traded goods over ten years.
• An agricultural trade accord was signed in November 1996 to address remaining trade barriers not covered by the FTA.
• Despite agreements, some non-tariff barriers and tariffs on goods still exist between Israel and the U.S.
• Israel has trade and cooperation agreements with the European Union and Canada, and seeks similar agreements with Turkey, Jordan, and several Eastern European countries.
• The European Union is Israel's top destination for exports; between October 2011 and January 2012, Israel exported US$5 billion worth of goods to the EU, representing 35% of total exports.
• During the same period, Israel's exports to East Asia and the Far East totaled approximately US$3.1 billion.

• Until 1995, Israel's trade with the Arab world was minimal due to the Arab League boycott initiated in 1945, which included primary, secondary, and tertiary boycotts against companies operating in or with Israel.
• In 2013, commercial trade between Israel and the Palestinian territories was valued at approximately US$20 billion annually.

• In 2012, ten companies accounted for 47.7% of Israel's exports; these included Intel Israel, Elbit Systems, Oil Refineries Ltd, Teva Pharmaceuticals, Iscar, Israel Chemicals, Makhteshim Agan, Paz Oil Company, Israel Aerospace Industries, and Hewlett-Packard's Indigo division.
• The Bank of Israel and Israel's Export Institute have warned that Israel's economy is overly dependent on a small number of exporters, posing potential risks.

• In 2016, Israel's top ten export destinations accounted for a significant portion of its total exports, with the United States leading at 32%, followed by Hong Kong at 8%, the United Kingdom at 7%, China at 6%, Belgium/Luxembourg at 4.5%, India at 4.3%, the Netherlands at 3.8%, Germany at 2.7%, Switzerland at 2.6%, and France at 2.6%.
• The total export volume to the United States in 2016 was approximately 17.6 billion US dollars, primarily consisting of cut diamonds and medicaments.
• Hong Kong's exports to Israel in 2016 amounted to about 4.44 billion US dollars, mainly consisting of cut diamonds.
• The United Kingdom exported approximately 3.91 billion US dollars to Israel in 2016, with medicaments being the primary export.
• China exported around 3.33 billion US dollars worth of goods to Israel in 2016, primarily electrical equipment and integrated circuits.
• Belgium and Luxembourg together exported about 2.51 billion US dollars to Israel in 2016, predominantly cut diamonds, as of 2015 data.
• India's exports to Israel in 2016 totaled approximately 2.4 billion US dollars, mainly cut diamonds.
• The Netherlands exported roughly 2.14 billion US dollars to Israel in 2016, with medicaments and computer equipment as the main exports.
• Germany's exports to Israel in 2016 were about 1.52 billion US dollars, with a varied range of products.
• Switzerland exported approximately 1.47 billion US dollars to Israel in 2016, primarily cut diamonds.
• France's exports to Israel in 2016 totaled around 1.45 billion US dollars, with a varied product range.

• In 2016, Israel's top ten import origins represented a diverse set of countries, with the United States leading at 13% of total imports, totaling about 8.1 billion US dollars, mainly diamonds and electronics.
• China (excluding Hong Kong) supplied Israel with approximately 5.9 billion US dollars worth of goods in 2016, with a varied product mix.
• Switzerland imported about 4.29 billion US dollars worth of goods into Israel in 2016, primarily oil, chemicals, and diamonds.
• Germany's imports from Israel in 2016 amounted to roughly 4.07 billion US dollars, covering a varied range of products.
• Belgium and Luxembourg together supplied approximately 3.91 billion US dollars to Israel in 2016, mainly diamonds, as of 2015 data.
• The United Kingdom exported around 3.67 billion US dollars worth of goods to Israel in 2016, primarily oil.
• The Netherlands' exports to Israel in 2016 were about 2.7 billion US dollars, mainly computers and electronics.
• Italy exported approximately 2.69 billion US dollars worth of goods to Israel in 2016, with a varied product range.
• Turkey's exports to Israel in 2016 totaled about 2.6 billion US dollars, covering a range of products.
• Japan supplied Israel with roughly 2.35 billion US dollars worth of goods in 2016, primarily cars and photo lab equipment.
• The data sources for these statistics are from the Observatory of Economic Complexity, archived on 11 May 2019 at the Wayback Machine, MIT.
• The Global Competitiveness Report of 2016 to 2017 ranked Israel as the world's second most innovative economy, highlighting its strong innovation capabilities.
• Israel was ranked 19th among 189 countries on the United Nations' Human Development Index, reflecting its high level of human development.
• As of 2018, Israel ranked 20th out of 133 countries on the economic complexity index, indicating a relatively diverse and sophisticated economy.
• The IMD World Competitiveness Yearbook of 2016 placed Israel as the 21st most competitive economy globally out of 61 surveyed economies.
• Israel's economy was ranked as the world's most durable economy in the face of crises, demonstrating resilience during global economic downturns.
• It was also ranked first in the rate of research and development center investments, emphasizing its focus on innovation and technological advancement.
• The Bank of Israel was ranked first among central banks for its efficient functioning, improving from 8th place in 2009.
• Israel was ranked first in the supply of skilled manpower, underscoring its highly educated and capable workforce.

• Israeli companies, especially in the high-tech sector, have achieved significant success raising capital on Wall Street and international financial markets; as of 2010, Israel ranked second among foreign countries in the number of companies listed on U.S. stock exchanges.
• Since moving away from a socialist economic model in the mid-1980s and early 1990s, Israel has transitioned toward a free-market capitalist economy.
• As of 2020, Israel's economic freedom score was 74.0, making it the 26th freest economy according to the 2020 Index of Economic Freedom.
• Israel ranked 35th on the World Bank's ease of doing business index, indicating a relatively favorable business environment.
• The country's economic competitiveness is supported by strong protection of property rights, relatively low levels of corruption, and high openness to global trade and investment.
• Income and corporate tax rates in Israel remain relatively high compared to other nations.
• In 2020, Israel ranked 35th out of 179 countries on Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index, indicating moderate perceptions of corruption.
• Bribery and other forms of corruption are illegal in Israel, which is a signatory to the OECD Bribery Convention since 2008.
• In April 2024, Fitch, one of the three leading U.S. credit rating agencies, issued a warning that the Gaza war could cause a significant decline in Israel's credit metrics.
• In August 2024, Fitch downgraded Israel's credit rating due to geopolitical tensions.
• The credit rating of Israel was further downgraded to Baa1 by Moody's in the following month, September 2024.
• In October 2024, S&P also downgraded Israel's credit rating, reflecting concerns over regional instability and economic outlook.
